awd_titl_txt: New Tools for Analyzing Complex Network and Text Data
awd_abstract_narration:
Network data and text data are frequently found in many different areas of science and business (for example, social networks, genetic networks, news,  tweets, and blogs). A problem of great interest in statistics and machine learning is how to extract information from network data and text data. The research in this project will have several components:  (a) collecting and cleaning large-scale network data sets and text data sets,  (b)  developing new models, methods, and theory for analyzing network data and text data, and (c) analyzing a large data set, which the PI and collaborators have collected and cleaned (the data set is on the publication data of statisticians). The research will have an impact in social science, business, and especially in understanding the publication patterns and trends of statisticians. The project also provides training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students. 

Network data and text data are widely available and contain valuable information for answering many scientific problems. This project will focus on network analysis and text learning and will make contributions in the following topics:   (a) development of models for network and text data,  (b) development of computationally feasible approaches to network global testing, pairwise comparison,  dynamic network analysis, and text learning,  and (c) development of new approaches for studying the research patterns and trends of the statistical community. The research will lead to new data sets and new methods and theory in the application areas of social networks, genetic networks, and text mining, and will have an impact in social science, business, and biology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Complex network, tensor, and text data are frequently found in many scientific areas and daily lives (e.g., social networks, genetic networks, news articles, tweets). How to extract information from such data is a problem of great interest,  and a deeper understanding of which will benefit science, business, and even daily life in a long way.   

The project has developed many novel ideas and methods to address an array of challenging problems in network analysis, dynamic networks, topic modeling, topic trends, journal ranking,  citation prediction, among others.   This includes  a tool for estimating the mixed memberships in network called the Mixed-SCORE, and a self-normalizing cycle count statistics (SCC) for network testing and for estimating the number of network communities, among others. These methods are shown to be optimal. The project has also made a significant contribution in collecting and analyzing the MADStat, a large-scale high quality data set on the statistical publications.  Especially, using the MADStat data set,  the project discovers that there is a so-called statistical triangle in the spectral domain, where the vertices of the triangle represents the three primary areas in statistics which can be interpreted as "Bayes", ``Biostatistics", and ``non-parametric statistics", respectively. Such findings help understand the research trends and research patterns of the statistical community, and the underlying approach is readily extendable to study the publication data of other fields (e.g., physics, cancer research).    

The proposed research benefits the Statistical Science by providing new data sets, new projects, and by recruiting new personnel (e.g., collaborators and students). It also benefits scientists in many areas (e.g., social networks, text analysis, cancer study, public health) with an array of new tools. The project has also produced easy-to-implement softwares that may help individual researcher and administrators (in universities or funding agencies) in understanding the research trends and the social networks of researchers.  The results are widely disseminated through journal and conference publications, presentations, and publicly available software packages.   The project has also provided opportunities for students to train and build professional networks in a highly active area of modern statistics.
